handNotes.handNote: Red crayon or thick red pencil. Probably a different hand from Mitford's that marks many of her letters, sometimes drawing diagonal lines across pages, and sometimes writing words overtop and perpendicularly across Mitford's writing.
Someone, apparently other than Mitford, perhaps cataloging letters and describing them, who left grey pencil marks and numbered her letters now in the Reading Central Library's collection.
Someone, apparently other than Mitford, perhaps cataloging letters and describing them, who left grey pencil marks on her letters now in the John Rylands Library's collection.

Someone, apparently other than Mitford, who occasionally left notes in a spidery thin hand to explain or document details in Mitford's letters in the margins of her pages, noted in the manuscripts held at Reading Central Library. This may be William Harness or A. G. L'Estrange.

editorialDecl.p: Mitford’s spelling and punctuation are retained, except where a word is split at the end of a line and the beginning of the next in the manuscript. Where Mitford’s spelling and hyphenation of words deviates from the standard, in order to facilitate searching we are using the TEI elements choice, sic, and reg to encode both Mitford’s spelling and the regular international standard of Oxford English spelling, following the first listed spelling in the Oxford English Dictionary. The long s and ligatured forms are not encoded.

div.p:
You are a very sly man with your stories of Lord Morley's look--(a capital story it is to be sure! he must be a clever person that Lord Morley, though his reputation has merged in hiswife's, who is perhaps as much over as he is under-rated)--You are a sly man, my dear Sir William, & know perfectly well where to take me--or rather you were conscious of your power (as all men are of their power over women) & knew that is you said Do so I should do it. So here I am writing--I can't get a frank though within the appointed time--but you are rich (not like we poor Authors) & would I believe rather pay for a letter than get not get one--So here I am--resolved to make the most of a sheet for your satisfaction. In the first place I should scold you for not telling me exactly how your arm is, if the steady writing of that delightful letter were not a proof that it is getting strength--In the second I prefer, I think, of two very good Inscriptions the second--that which begins with not only--& would I think stop at Institution--But I am no judge at all of this sort of writing--It is a very gratifying compliment to his surviving family--Pray have you heard (talking of monuments) the strange story of Lord Byron's consignment to Mr. Murray? It may be in the newspapers--for I do not see them--but it came to me in the freshness of M.S. from a literary friend & I shall tell you the story at a venture. Lord Byron has sent to Murray a dead child to be interred in the Harrow Churchyard in a spot particularly pointed out with directions to have a splendid Mausoleum erected to over it--but if that be not permitted, then a Tablet is to be placed in a part of the Church also indicated where his eye used to rest while
a school boy with the Inscription "He shall not come to me but I shall go to him." Very appropriate when one remembers on what occasion David spoke those words.--Many thanks for the Scott story--It looks like confession--but I have no doubt. I agree with you that there is an infinite charm in the Fortunes of Nigel--in the manners & characters--King Jamie above all--the love story is of course nothing, & rather worse than nothing--for certainly the heroine is by no means pretty behaved--but there is a life, a vitality about it--There is so much salt that it will keep--to parody Dr. Johnson's expression respecting the Rehearsal--& above all there are no witches--thank Heaven! I hope he has done with them. Halidon Hill was a most complete & comfortable failure--Did you not think so?--for the which I also laud the Gods--If he had once taken to play writing the Lord of mercy upon us poor spinsters of Tragedy--He would have supplied Covent Garden, Drury Lane, theHaymarket, the Cobourg, the Surrey the very English Opera House!--But Halidon Hill is a Damper--& his reputation is so splendid & so various that he can afford to have failed in the one little point with regards to which he was himself so doubtful--My Tragedy with its new Fifth Act is still with Mr. Kemble--& still will remain there of course.--Till I hear whether he wishes for any farther alteration I have no legible copy, & scarcely the heart to make one--So that I cannot gratify your kind curiosity. I do hope that some time next season I shall be able to send it to you in print--which will be every way more satisfactory. But really I try all I can not to think about it--I have been so worn out with expectation & anxiety & alteration. You will find it very different from the trumpery I used to write--though still too womanish.--Our Poet here Mr. Milman is in Italy--Did I tell you a little story of him in my last? I think
not. If I did you must forgive the repetition. He was you must know a sun-worshipper--a salamander--never hot in his life, seldom warm--Well about 6 weeks ago he was met by a gentleman in this neighborhood half way up a hill in Italy--his coat & waistcoat on one side of him--his hat with his neck-cloth in it on the other--& himself in the act of divesting himself of another article of his habiliments (in short his drawers) intending to accomplish the rest of the hill in his shirt & trowsers. You don't know the man I believe--so can scarcely image to yourself what a perfection of gawkiness that uncravatted craggy neck would exhibit!--Really--I ought not to laugh at him--for he is very kind to me--don't give me for your authority if you should happen to tell the story.--We have had today a very great & unexpected pleasure--that of hearing from a friend whom we had entirely lost sight of during fifteen years. She was then a most interesting young women in most interesting circumstances. her husband, a young Officer in the guards the eldest son of a man of large property, had been taken prisoners during their bridal tour & shut up at Verdun--After a long detention she obtained leave to arrange for remittance to return home & brought with her her little boy--She was in London then & so were we & passed much time together--when she had acomplished her business, she took her passage to return to her husband--when suddenly her father in law declared that she might go if she chose but that her boy should stay--he would not have his heir brought up in a foreign Country--It was a terrible struggle--but she did rightly as I think--she joined her husband & left the child with its Grandfather. Since then we have never heard of
till today--She had lost our address in the Country--& only found us out accidentally through the insertion of my Father's name in some justicing affair in the Windsor Paper where they are quartered. Only think what a pleasure it will be to see her--Mama and her Mother were old friends, so that we were so very intimate--But now we shall be all altered! She is I see just the same from her letter--just as kind & warm hearted & charming as ever--but to think of that lovely young woman with a parcel of great boys & girls--that is astounding enough--but nothing to what she will feel in seeing the little shy quiet girl she remembers so kindly turned into a person of my rotundity--an old maid--& an Authoress that is the worst part of the business--I am afraid she will be sadly shocked at that.--the lady of an Officer in the 1st Life Guards must of necessity & of station have a great horror of a person who writes at so much per sheet!--Goodbye my very dear friend--On looking over this letter I see that it seems fatigued--which I supposed because I that write it am tired with a long ride & walk yesterday--ride & walk yesterday--ride & walk & talk--for it was the last I believe that did me up--I went with a young friend to show her Silchester & really when we came back we were both forced
to go to bed & have not got over it yet so fatiguing a thing is going a pleasuring.--God bless you my dear friend. I hope that Mrs. Adams is quite well again & every thing going on prosperously. Do not fail to make my very best & earnest to Miss Elford & accept the same from all here.
